text: This study aimed to examine empathy within human-chatbot interactions among computer science students at Uppsala University in Sweden. Specifically, the research explored participants' perceptions of anthropomorphic chatbots, instances of verbal abuse during interactions, and how gender dynamics influence expectations of chatbot helpfulness. The qualitative data collection involved semi-structured interviews with five students, and thematic analysis was used for data analysis. Results indicated that empathy is present in human-chatbot interactions regardless of participants' perceptions of chatbots as human-like or machine-like. However, the level of empathy was generally low, with participants expressing frustration when dissatisfied with chatbot responses. Additionally, participants may anticipate more assistance and courteousness from chatbots perceived as female.
name: new-043
